sp.p: Ah, the Key's broke in the Lock! undone, undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I am ruin'd if my Mother finds me here.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! What will become of me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake hide your ſelf, do Mr Gerald, I'le love you dearly for it.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: How? Where? I'le do any thing my dear will have me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Here's the Coffin the dead body was ſent in from the Gallows, you may hide your ſelf in that.

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p: Ay do, Mr Gerald, do.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: How! Coffin me before I am dead, I beg your pardon; I can't endure the thought on't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Thou ſtrip your ſelf to your Waſtcoat, and your Drawers, and lye at your length, here on this Table, I'le tell my Maſter you're the dead body, ſent in to be diſſected.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Quickly, Mr Gerald; if you love me deny me not Knocking all this while.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Come then, I'le do any thing my, Dear Commands me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Hark how they knock; I fear they'll break the door down.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Ho! Beatrice, Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Make haſte, or we're undone. They ſtrip him.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Open the door! Why Beatrice, where are

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: So, ſo; what e're they ſay or do, be ſure you ſtir not for your life.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Where will you hide my Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Here, here, I • le put them and my young Miſtreſs into the Coffin. Knock again. I am coming preſently.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: So, ſo; I am dead as a Herring.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What ever happens, Sir, be not afraid. Come in.

div.stage: Enter Criſpin like a Doctor. Young Ger diſguis'd like his man. I thought I heard my Maſter and my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: They come here preſently; but where, where be the dead Carcaſs for diſſection?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Ver—good—Mr Doctor, ſend me to begind manuel operation upon de exterior, an den he will come hear me read upon de interior—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Are you the German Doctor; that wase her this morning with my Maſter?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Yes, de-ver—ſame, me am de German Doctor, de Medicine, de Phyſitien, de Operateur, de Anatomiſt, de Chymiſt, de—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, have you any ſervice for me?

sp.speaker: Cr • ſ.
sp.p: Stay one little time. Dis be de Body, let me make de obſervation of the Viſage—here be de ver ill aſpect— dis was one perſon of de fair Speech, but de fals Heart; covetous, deſigning, letcherous; a Robber, a Thief, a Cut-throat—Sacrament, hanging was too good for him, a Rogue, a Villain—ah vat pleaſure will dis be to make de Diſſection, de Inciſion, and de Amputation, upon dis Body, and rip open his Belly from de Cartilage Ziphode, quite along to his Os-pubis. Ah! vat be dis? his Heart pant ſtill—dis was the ſtubborn old Thief, was but Mr Doctor here, juſt a now, I would ſhew him de Circulation of de Blood, thro de Syſtole, and Diaſtole. Come I'le begin de Diſſection while de body be warm.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What before my Maſter comes?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Yes indeed, dis be only de Manuel Operation, me vil read de Lecture ven he be here: vare be my man, vare be de Inſtruments? Y. G. Here, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what's that great Knife for?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Dis be to cut de Troat, from Jugular to Jugular; as thus.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Hold Sir, I beſeech you. Fear nothing, Mr Gerald. [aſide

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee preſently.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: 'Tis juſt like one of our Butchers Knives: and then what is that Ax for?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Dis be de decolation Ax, to cut off de head at one Chop; as thus—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Not yet Sir: What's that there like a Wimble?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Dat be to bore a hole in de Scull; when any part of de Scull be broke, and depreſs'd upon de Brain, with dis we bore hole hard by de fracture, as you ſhall ſee juſt-a-now.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: No Sir, not now; I'll ſee't anon.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Den we put in de proper Inſtrument, and raiſe de depreſſure up to de proper place, and ſo make de cure.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: But what is this terrible Saw for?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Dat be de diſmembring Saw, to Saw off de Leg, or de Arm: You ſee me preſentale Saw off de Bone of dis Leg, and—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Stay Sir; What's that ſharp crooked Knife for?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Dis be de Amputation Knife, to cut off de Leg or de Hand, juſt-a in de Joynt. Ha! where be de Leg and be Arm?—

div.stage: Criſpin draws one Leg from the other, and one Arm from his Body, and Gerald draws 'em cloſe to him again.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: De Devil! me lay one Arm here, and one Leg here, to Saw off juſt in the middle, and cut off juſt in de Joynt, for de fine experiment; and de Arm, and de Leg, be gone home to de Body.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Mr Dr. we come for the Coffin we brought the dead Body in.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p:
Dere be de Coffin; be gone; and give me no interruption; now I open all de Breaſt. [Criſ. tears open his Waſtcoot.
So, now with dis Inſtrument, dis [The men carry off the Coffin. Knife, I will in one moment cut de Breaſt-bone, from de Ribs, and lay all open, dat you ſhall ſee how de Heart, de Lungs, de Liver, lie in dair place proper, and order natural. O de Devil, agen! de Body ſhrink! de Leg move; and de Arm too: vat ſtrange Carcaſs have you in dis Country?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, I have ſeen whole Bodies, after they have lain here a day or two, get up, and run away.

sp.speaker: O. Ger.
sp.p: And ſo will I! I'll not ſtay to be butcher'd here. He leaps off the Table.

sp.speaker: Criſ, & Bea.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: O. Ger.
sp.p: Loſe my Cloaths, my Life, and Jewels all at once!—Your Servant, Mr Doctor.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Stop Thief, ſtop Thief. As old Gerald is running out, and Criſpin after him, the Doctor and his Wife enter. O. Gerald runs againſt the Doctor, beats the Doctor and his Wife down, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: O murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay, murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wounds! Where's this Dog of a Doctor? I'le knock the old Cheat's Brains out.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And if I can reach him, I'le claw his Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: O am bruis d all over!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And I am lam'd too.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: O are you there?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wounds, Doctor, you have ſcour'd my Guts out, with a murrain to ye—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And I can hardly draw my Legs after me, for your Phyſick. But I'le claw you for't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Hold, Miſtreſs, or I ſhall pluck a Crow with you.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Be patient Wife—you are both mad. I never ſaw either of you before.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O damn'd lying Doctor! did you not give me Pills? and I gave you a whole half Guinea?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And had not I ſome of your Rot-gut Pills too, and gave you 2 new Crown-pieces?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: You rave both, and muſt be ſent to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Sbud I'le have my money again—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And ſo will I,—or tear his Eyes out—

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Hold friends! pray moderate your angers, and don't affront a perſon of our faculty.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ah, ha! I was miſtaken, this is the Doctor—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: I this is he gave us the Pills. I beg your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Beatrice, you muſt refund.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: There—

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Look you friends, 'twas a miſtake. There's your Half Guinea, and your Crown-pieces too.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O pox! this is ſomething.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this▪

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Beatrice, what is the matter here?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What ſtrange out-cry was that we heard?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I, and who threw us down?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And what ſtrange thing was that ran over us?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, as I was ſhewing Mr Doctor here the
dead Body that was ſent you from the Gallows, he felt his pulſe, and laying his hand on his Breaſt, he found his Heart panted; then he took his Inciſion Knife, and before he could touch his naked skin, up ſtarted the dead Body, and ran away, juſt as you ſaw—

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: All this is true, Sir, as I am a Member of the learned Faculty.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I am amaz'd▪

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay Husband, I have heard of ſuch ſtrange things: I warrant the poor man was hang'd wrongfully.

sp.speaker: O. Ger.
sp.p: O undone! undone!

sp.speaker: Wife & Bea.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He's come again, Husband, ha!

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: In the name of goodneſs! What art thou?

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Undone I ſay, undone.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Art thou a Spirit? or Fleſh and Blood? anſwer.

sp.speaker: O. G
sp.p: Give me my Cloaths, my Jewels, Huſwife—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Avant, avant!

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Where are they? Gipſy, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: In the Coffin, in the Coffin.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: I overtook the Coffin, and there's none of 'em. Where are they, and the Jilt too your young Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Sure 'tis our Neighbour, Mr Gerald.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: I am the ſame.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You tell me wonders, Criſpin.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Step to your Daughter's Chamber, Madam; there the Riddle will eaſily be unfolded▪

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What is the matter, Sir? why in this poſture? and why this out-cry too?

sp.speaker: O. O.
sp.p: That Baggage there, and the young Witch your Daughter, have contriv'd to abuſe and cheat me, of two thouſand pounds worth of Jewels, that were pawnd to me.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Here they come then, who muſt give you ſatisfaction.

div.stage: Enter VVife and Young Gerald, leading in Angelica, dreſs'd in the Jewels.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: How! my Son here!

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and my Wife.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: I found 'em ſhut up together in my Daughter's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Married ſay you?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, contracted long ſince; and now confirm'd in private, as far as modeſty would permit.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: And Married too! then all is at an end.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Here are your Cloaths, Sir, Doctor Criſpin can tell you how I came by 'em.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Criſpin!

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: My Rogue.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Non Rogus; Medicus ſum; that is, I am a German, or a Poliſh Doctor.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: The Jewels, Sir, ſo well become my Wife, I think you cannot in conſcience demand 'em back.

sp.speaker: Ang▪
sp.p: They were his own free gift; he ſcorns to take what he has given me.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: Well. I am glad the Son has married my Daughter, and wiſh Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Bleſs you together. Come Brother Gerald, 'tis your Son's Wedding Night; you muſt forgive 'em and be ſociable: Let me prevail with you to give order for a good Supper, and we'll be very merry, Brother.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: I had as good, I ſhall be laught at elſe.
Sirrah▪ here has been fine practice, and my Son's marriage was your contrivance.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: I do confeſs it, Sir, and glory in the ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Come then, ſit down, and liſten to the Muſick, and after Supper we'll hear at large the adventures of Doctor Criſpin in this Affair.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Beatrice and I will tell you he whole Story,
And as we ſnack'd the Fees, we'll ſhare the Glory.

div.stage: The Fourth and laſt Muſical Entertainment. After that, the Curtain falls.
